H0.text: As coal is heated, some of the molecules move so fast that they are destroyed, which explains why the electrical energy produced is less than the coal’s potential energy.

H1.text: Some of the energy in coal is destroyed by the intense heat required to release its potential energy, which explains why the electrical energy produced when coal is burned to generate electricity is less than the coal’s potential energy.

H2.text: Some of the potential energy in coal is converted into forms of energy other than electricity when coal is burned to produce electricity, explaining why the electrical energy produced is less than the potential energy in the coal.

H3.text: The amount of potential energy in fuels is overestimated when coal is burned to produce electricity, because the electrical energy produced is less than the potential energy contained in the coal.

A4.text: Thus chemical energy stored in coal is converted successively into thermal energy, mechanical energy and, finally, electrical energy.

A5.text: The heat from the burning pulverized coal converts boiler water to steam, which is then used to spin turbines that turn generators.
